channel.title: Elementary Physics
channel.description:
ok look at this question:
a ball is thrown downwards from a 12.5m tower with a initial speed of 4.5m/s...determine the speed at which it hits the ground and the time interval..
now i did it like this..simple..
Vi=4.5m/s a=9.81m/s d=12.5m Vf=? delta T=?
[Vf]^2= [Vi]^2 + 2ad
i find Vf = 16.28 m/s
now to find delta T : Vf = Vi +at
t=[Vf-Vi]/a and found t=1.2s
now my text book says Vf=23.9m/s and t=.597s.. i duno if i'm wrong or the text book is being gay help me :p.. i think wat i did was rite

item.title: Elementary Physics
item.dc:creator: @runescape3dude runescape3dude
item.description:
@runescape3dude wrote:

GTFO. Why would a text book ‘have a built in calculator?’

It has an answers section in it somewhere. Or a conversion table.

  • This guy solved the problems…

@SETO, this is uni? I thought elementary meant like elementary school.

Read full topic

yea, thanks man, i did that too but needed assurance, first week of physics in uni :p, haven’t done much physics in 5 Months…my brain still needs clean up…soon we are starting n-t coordinates, boy that will be fun

item.dc:creator: @runescape3dude runescape3dude
item.description:
@runescape3dude wrote:

The book is wrong…
I worked the equation backwards from the text book’s answer and I got 1.98 S for the time interval, not 0.597 S
